On Mon, Jun 9, 2008 at 8:34 PM, Robert Wenner <robert.wenner@...> wrote:=

>
> On Monday 09 June 2008 21:18, C=E9dric Beust wrote:
> > > If I have to=
 go through umpteen thousand lines of log, I may as well
> > > test everyth=
ing manually.
> >
> > Nobody says you have to, but the fact that your tests=
 pass doesn't
> > guarantee that you are testing what you think you are tes=
ting.
>
> Well. If the log is important, I have to go through it, or I miss=

> something important. If it is not important (and I don't have to go
> th=
rough it) I can skip it altogether. So what do you mean when you say I
> do=
n't have to go through it?

It's the definition of a log:  most of the time=
, you don't need it,
but it's handy if you need to double check something a=
fter your tests
have run.

> > Which is why reports are an integral part of=
 a testing framework.
>
> For BDD, I agree.

Not just for BDD, not sure why=
 you want to single this out.

I know of organizations that commit all the =
test results (HTML and
others) to databases every day so they can run long-=
term statistics
and various other metrics over the course of time.

--
C=E9=
